questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with recurrent, painful nodules and abscesses in her axillae .She has a history of smoking and obesity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis Suppurativa

  • Pathophysiology: Involves follicular occlusion, infection with Staphylococcus aureus or Propionibacterium acnes, leading to chronic painful abscesses and scarring.
  • Affected Areas: Primarily the axillae and groin, but can also affect the scalp, breast, and perineum.
  • Risk Factors: Smoking, obesity, and hormonal influences (often starts at puberty and resolves after menopause).
  • Management:
    • Lifestyle Changes: Stop smoking, lose weight.
    • Topical Treatments: Antiseptic soaps, tea tree oil.
    • Medical Treatments: Antibiotics (topical or oral), anti-androgen drugs.
    • Surgical: Radical excision of affected skin in severe cases with reconstruction to prevent contracture.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Hidradenitis suppurativa: Correct. This condition is characterised by recurrent, painful abscesses in apocrine gland-bearing areas (axillae, groin), often associated with smoking and obesity.

Option B) Pyoderma gangrenosum: Incorrect. Pyoderma gangrenosum is an ulcerative condition associated with underlying systemic diseases like inflammatory bowel disease.

OPTION C) Folliculitis: Incorrect. While folliculitis involves inflammation of hair follicles, it does not lead to chronic abscess formation or sinus tracts.

OPTION D) Cellulitis: Incorrect. Cellulitis presents with diffuse skin infection, usually without nodules or abscesses localised to apocrine gland-bearing skin.

Key Points:

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, painful condition affecting apocrine gland areas.
  • Strong association with smoking, obesity, and hormonal factors.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with lesions around the nose and mouth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impetigo

  • Superficial infection caused by Staphylococci, Streptococci, or both.
  • Clinical Features: Honey-coloured crusts
  • commonly affecting children.
  • Treatment: Washing the area, topical antistaphylococcal treatments, and oral antibiotics if streptococcal infection is present.

Explanation:

Option A) Cellulitis typically presents with diffuse erythema and swelling, not crusted lesions.

Option B) Correct. Impetigo is characterised by honey-coloured crusts, often seen in children.

Option C) Erysipelas presents as sharply demarcated erythema, usually on the face or legs, not with crusting.

Option D) Lymphangitis presents with red streaks along the lymphatics, not crusted lesions

Key Points:

Highly infectious and common in children. Honey-colored crust is the hallmark feature.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a sharply demarcated erythematous and oedematous area on the face, associated with fever and leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erysipelas

  • A streptococcal infection of the superficial lymphatics.
  • Clinical Features: Sharply demarcated erythema, often on the face.
  • Treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics, usually after culture and sensitivity testing.

Explanation:

Option A) Cellulitis is more generalised, without sharp demarcation.

Option B) Impetigo presents with honey-coloured crusts, not with sharply demarcated erythema.

Option C) Correct. Erysipelas presents with sharply demarcated erythema, often associated with systemic symptoms.

Option D) Lymphangitis presents with red streaks, not sharply demarcated erythema.

Key Points:

Sharply demarcated erythema with systemic symptoms like fever. Commonly associated with broken skin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless lumps over scrotum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Epidermal Cysts

  • Cysts lined with stratified squamous epithelium
  • derived from hair follicles.
  • Clinical Features: Fixed to the skin with a central punctum.
  • Treatment:
    • Incision and drainage if infected
    • excision once inflammation subsides.
  • Meibomian cysts are epidermal cysts found on the free edge of the eyelid.
  • Trichilemmal (pilar/pilosebaceous) cysts are derived from the epidermis of the external root sheath of the hair follicle; 90% are found in the scalp and 70% are multiple. They are usually distinguished from epidermal cysts by pathologists, rather than clinically.

Explanation:

Option A) Lipoma is a soft, movable lump, usually without a central punctum.

Option B) Correct. Epidermal cysts are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Option C) Meibomian cysts are epidermal cysts found on the free edge of the eyelid.

Option D) Abscess presents with fluctuation and signs of infection.

Key Points:

  • Epidermal cysts also called sebaceous cysts.Should be excised completely to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a flat, deeply pigmented lesion on the arm, noticed since childhood. It has not grown recently, and there is no history of trauma. What is the most likely type of nevus?
questions.solution:
Compound Nevus: A maculopapular lesion, typically more prominent during adolescence, involving both the dermis and the epidermis.

Junctional Nevus: Characterised by a proliferation of nevus cells at the dermoepidermal junction, appearing as deeply pigmented macules or papules, most common in childhood or adolescence.

Intradermal Nevus: Faintly pigmented papules in adults, with nevus cells located in the dermis, showing no junctional activity.

Spitz Nevus: Reddish-brown nodules that may resemble melanoma, commonly found on the face or legs, often requiring excision biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

  • Blue Nevus: A benign skin lesion typically found in children, often involving extremities and face.
  • Nevus of Ota and Ito: Dermal melanocytic hamartomas that present as blue or grey macules on the face (Ota) or shoulder (Ito), commonly seen in women, especially of Asian or African descent.

Key Points:

  • Spitz Nevus can mimic melanoma and needs biopsy if suspicious.
  • Naevus of Ota commonly affects the V1 and V2 dermatomes and is more frequent in Asian and African individuals.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a pearly nodule on his face.He has a long history of sun exposure due to outdoor work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma

  • Slow-growing: Locally invasive, rarely metastasizes.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic UVR exposure, light skin, age 40-80, and living near the equator.
  • Most Common Subtypes: Nodular (90% of cases) with a pearly surface and telangiectasia.
  • High-Risk BCC: Large tumours(>2cm ), recurrent, or located near high-risk areas like eyes and nose. (tear area)Can invade bone or cause severe local destruction.
  • Management: Surgical excision (Mohs' micrographic surgery for high-risk cases).
  • Tumour and surrounding surgical margins should always be assessed and marked under loupe magnification, the latter varying between 2 and 15 mm depending on the macroscopic variant.
  • Radiotherapy in elderly patients or for inoperable cases. Topical therapies like 5-fluorouracil or imiquimod for superficial BCC.

Explanation:

Option A) Melanoma usually presents as a pigmented lesion with asymmetry, irregular borders, and rapid growth.

Option B) Correct. BCC is characterised by a pearly, translucent nodule with overlying telangiectasia, often associated with chronic sun exposure.

Option C) SCC usually presents as a more ulcerative lesion with scaling, often related to chronic inflammation or sun damage.

Option D) Actinic Keratosis presents as rough, scaly patches, and is considered a precursor to SCC.

Key Points:

Nodular BCC is the most common subtype (90%).UVR is the strongest risk factor.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcer on his scalp, which has been increasing in size over the past few months. He has a history of chronic sun exposure due to his profession as a farmer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

  • Associated Factors: Chronic sun exposure, chronic inflammation (burn scars, osteomyelitis), immunosuppression, and chemical carcinogens (e.g., arsenicals).
  • Risk Factors: UVR, smoking, HPV infection, and prior skin injuries.
  • Types: High-risk SCC (due to size, location, or histology) can metastasize in up to 30% of cases.
  • Clinical Presentation: Non-healing ulcer, often in sun-exposed areas. May arise from actinic keratosis or chronic wounds (e.g., Marjolin's ulcer).

Explanation:

Option A) BCC typically presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than an ulcerative lesion.

Option B) Bowen's disease is an SCC in situ and presents as a scaly erythematous patch rather than an ulcer.

Option C) Correct. SCC commonly presents as a non-healing ulcer, especially in sun-exposed areas, and is strongly associated with cumulative sun damage.

Option D) Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that may lead to SCC but presents as rough, scaly patches rather than an ulcer.

Key Points:

SCC has a higher metastatic potential than BCC, especially in high-risk cases. Actinic keratosis is a precursor to SCC.. Bowen's disease is SCC in situ.

choices.text: SCC arising from burn scars has a lower metastatic potential.
Lesions >6 mm deep have a higher chance of metastasis.
SCC on the trunk has a worse prognosis than on the extremities.
Surgical excision requires a minimum 2 cm margin for lesions <2 cm.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 3 cm non-healing ulcer on his ear. A biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with a Broder's grade III. Which of the following statements is true regarding SCC?
questions.solution:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

  • Broder's Grading: Histological grading based on the degree of differentiation.
  • Prognostic Factors:
    • Depth: >6 mm depth = 15% metastasis risk.
    • Lesion Size: >2 cm lesions have a worse prognosis.
    • Histology: Higher Broder's grade indicates worse prognosis.
    • Site: Tumours on the lips/ears have higher recurrence.
    • High-Risk Factors: Arising from chronic ulcers, burn scars, and in immunosuppressed patients.

Management: Surgical excision with a margin based on tumour size (4 mm margin for <2 cm, 1 cm for larger lesions).

Option A) Incorrect. SCC arising from burn scars (Marjolin's ulcer) has a higher metastatic potential.

Option B) Correct. SCC lesions with greater depth of invasion (>6 mm) are associated with increased risk of metastasis.

Option C) Incorrect. SCC on the head, neck, or mucosal surfaces has a worse prognosis than on the trunk or extremities.

Option D) Incorrect. For lesions <2 cm, a 4-6 mm margin is generally sufficient

Key Points:

  • Lesions deeper than 6 mm or larger than 2 cm have poor prognosis.
  • Surgical margins depend on tumour size and depth.

questions.text: A 30-year-old fair-skinned woman presents with a changing mole. Biopsy reveals superficial spreading melanoma. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this patient?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous Malignant Melanoma

  • Epidemiology:
    • Accounts for <5% of skin cancers but causes >75% of skin cancer deaths.
    • Incidence linked to UV exposure, especially in fair-skinned individuals.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Genetic predispositions (family history, genetic syndromes).
    • UV exposure: Chronic (lentigo maligna) vs acute intense (superficial spreading).
    • Immunosuppression increases risk by 20-30 fold.
  • Prognostic Factors:
    • Breslow Thickness: Most important factor; depth of invasion.
  • Sentinel Node Biopsy (SNB): Staging.
  • Management: Surgical excision, sentinel node biopsy for staging, adjuvant therapy for advanced cases.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Breslow thickness: Correct. Breslow thickness (the depth of tumour invasion) is the most important prognostic factor in melanoma. Deeper melanomas have a worse prognosis.

Option B) Age at diagnosis: Incorrect. Age may have some impact, but it is not the most important prognostic factor compared to tumour thickness.

Option C) Gender: Incorrect. Gender has some influence on melanoma survival rates but is not a major prognostic factor.

Option D) Sun exposure history: Incorrect. While excessive sun exposure is a risk factor for developing melanoma, it does not directly affect prognosis after the diagnosis is made.

Key Points:

Breslow Thickness is the single most important prognostic indicator.

Rising Incidence: Especially in fair-skinned individuals with UV exposure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a rapidly growing blue papule on his neck that has developed over the past 3 months. The lesion is sharply demarcated, measuring 1.5 cm in diameter. He has no previous history of moles in this area. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely variant of malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
Option A) Incorrect. SSM typically arises in a pre-existing mole and grows slowly over years, before rapid progression in its vertical growth phase.

Option B) Correct. Nodular melanoma tends to present as a rapidly growing, sharply demarcated, blue/black papule, often arising de novo and typically found on the trunk, head, or neck.

Option C) Incorrect. LMM generally presents as a slow-growing, variegated brown macule on sun-exposed areas like the face or hands, often in elderly patients.

Option D) Incorrect. ALM affects the soles and palms, more commonly in darker-skinned individuals, and presents as a flat macule, often amelanotic.

Key Points:

  • Hutchinson's Sign: Pigmentation of the nail fold in subungual melanoma.
  • Desmoplastic Melanoma: Found on the head/neck with a propensity for perineural infiltration; often amelanotic.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with a skin lesion that is suspected to be melanoma. The lesion is excised, and the pathology report shows a Breslow thickness of 1.5 mm with no ulceration. What is the most important next step in staging this patient?
questions.solution:
Melanoma Management:

Biopsy:

  • Excision biopsy with a 2-3 mm margin is ideal for diagnosis.
  • Incision biopsy is done in cases where excision would be disfiguring (e.g., large lesions on the face).

Staging:

  • Breslow thickness: The most critical prognostic factor (measured from the granular layer to the tumor base).
  • AJCC staging: Accounts for lymph node involvement, distant metastases, and other prognostic factors.

 Local Treatment:

  • Melanoma in situ: Requires excision with a 5 mm margin.
  • Melanoma <1 mm: Excision with a 1 cm margin.
  • Melanoma >1 mm: A 2 cm margin is sufficient.

Regional Lymph Nodes:

  • Sentinel Node Biopsy (SNB): Offered for T2a or greater.
  • Completion lymphadenectomy is recommended after positive SNB for regional control.

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • BRAF mutations (50% of melanomas): Treated with dabrafenib or vemurafenib.
  • MAPK pathway inhibitors (e.g., trametinib) show promising results when combined with BRAF inhibitors.
  • Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ipilimumab, nivolumab) benefit in metastatic or unresectable melanoma.

Explanation

Option A) CT scan of the chest.Incorrect. Imaging is used for advanced disease, but the next step for staging in this case is sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Option B) Sentinel lymph node biopsy.Correct. For melanomas with a Breslow thickness >1 mm, sentinel lymph node biopsy is the standard next step for staging.

Option C) Chemotherapy Incorrect. Chemotherapy is not the first-line approach for early-stage melanoma.

Option D) Observation with regular follow-upIncorrect. While observation is part of management, sentinel lymph node biopsy is essential for staging first

Key Points:

  • Breslow thickness is the single most important factor in localized melanoma prognosis.
  • SLNB is critical for determining lymph node involvement in intermediate-thickness melanomas (>1 mm).

questions.text: A newborn presents with a pink macule at the nape of the neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Salmon Patch: A common vascular malformation that appears as a pinkish macule, often on the nape of the neck. It is caused by persistent fetal dermal circulation and usually disappears by 1 year of age.

Capillary Hemangioma: Appears as a bright red vascular tumor, usually seen on the head and neck, not as a flat macule.

Port-wine stain: Intense purple discoloration that does not resolve spontaneously.

Kaposi's Sarcoma: Rare malignant tumor, typically associated with immune compromise, presenting as red-brown plaques.

Key Point: Salmon patch resolves spontaneously within the first year of life.

questions.text: What percentage of capillary hemangiomas (strawberry naevi) resolve spontaneously by the age of 7 years?
questions.solution:
Capillary Hemangioma

  • Capillary Hemangioma: This is the most common vascular birthmark. 10% resolve each year after birth, with 70% resolving by 7 years of age.
  • Cause: Vascular malformation most commonly seen on the head and neck.
  • Epidemiology: More common in females and white-skinned individuals.

Key Point:

  • 70% of capillary hemangiomas resolve by 7 years of age.

questions.text: Kaposi's sarcoma is most commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Kaposi's Sarcoma: A malignant proliferative tumour of endothelial cells, strongly linked to human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and commonly associated with immune compromise, especially in HIV patients.
  • Other options: Turner syndrome, hypertension, and malaria are not linked to Kaposi's sarcoma.

Kaposi's Sarcoma

  • Cause: Human herpesvirus 8 infection.
  • Presentation: Red-brown indurated plaques, often nodular and ulcerated.
  • most commonly associated with immune compromise after transplantation or HIV infection
  • Treatment is with radiotherapy.

Key Point:

  • Kaposi's sarcoma is strongly associated with HIV infection.

questions.text: Angiosarcoma typically arises from which type of cells?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma

  • Cause: Malignant transformation of endothelial cells.
  • Presentation: Aggressive vascular tumor with rapid proliferation and early systemic spread.
  • Variants: Lymphangiosarcoma arises from lymphatic endothelium, often in chronically lymphoedematous tissue.

Explanation:

  • Angiosarcoma: A rare, highly malignant tumour arising from endothelial cells. It is characterised by rapid proliferation and early systemic spread.
  • Other options: Squamous epithelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and fibroblasts do not give rise to angiosarcomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a non-healing ulcer on his leg. Upon examination, the ulcer has an undermined edge. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ulcers and Sinuses

  • Ulcers: Discontinuity of epithelial surfaces. Classified as non-specific (shelving edge), specific (e.g., tuberculous with undermined edges), and malignant (e.g., basal cell carcinoma with a rolled edge).
  • Sinuses: Blind-ending tracts often resulting from abscesses. May be congenital (due to embryonic remnants) or acquired (e.g., from foreign bodies or infections).
  • Fistulas: Tracts connecting two epithelial surfaces, such as colocutaneous fistulas.

Explanation:

Option A) Non-specific ulcers have a shelving edge.

Option B) Correct. Tuberculous ulcers are characterised by undermined edges.

Option C) Basal cell carcinoma (rodent ulcer) presents with a rolled edge, often with visible blood vessels.

Option D) Syphilitic ulcers have a punched-out edge with a thin base covered by a "wash-leather" slough.

Key Points:

Tuberculous ulcers have undermined edges.non-specific ulcers have shelving edges.
